values:
Tagged by
bookbear
  :

Instructions: Each player starts with 7 random habits/facts about themselves. People who are tagged need to write on their own blog about their seven things, as well as these rules. At the end of your blog, you need to choose 7 people to get tagged & list their names. Don't forget to leave them a comment telling them that they have been tagged.

1.  My father was the first Japanese-American Officer ever in the US Navy.

2.  Since working at my current job, I have had to call the cops three times.  I've never had to do that before, and I've worked in both a bank and a gun store.



3.  Possibly the first R-rated movie I ever saw all the way through was an exploitation movie called Trip With The Teacher.    If I had to guess, I must have been seven or so.  My mom was staying overnight somewhere, and he was watching it--and there was a spot in my old house that you could see the rec room TV (which was the one that had cable) from the second floor (which is where my room was) without getting spotted by whoever was watching.  As a result, I saw pretty much the entire movie (only missing a little of the beginning).  What I remember of the movie is that it was about this all female class on a field trip (to the desert for some reason) who gets kidnpped and terrorized by a group of bikers (one of whom is played by Zalman King!)  The teacher, I remember, doesn't look all that much older than the students.  Anyway, the teacher is stripped entirely naked for pretty the whole movie (the evil bikers won't let her put her clothes back on).  Eventually, the teacher gets her bloody revenge--and I didn't sleep for a week.  I remember my dad telling my mom the next day, "Don't see 'Trip With The Teacher.'"  To this day, I've been trying to find a copy.

4. I actualy used to like Jive Bunny And The Mastermixers.

5. My late grandmother on my father's side, Shige Matsushita, had somehow gotten through her whole life without ever hearing, saying, or knowing what the word "fuck" meant, until she heard me say it.  I was 14 at the time, and I said it a LOT.  She went up to my mom and said, "Um, Geri?  what does the word 'Fuck' mean?  The kids seem to be saying it a lot."  (In truth, I was the only one, and my cousins complained to me later that my language was out of control.  Glad to see all of that has changed.)

6. I make my scrambled eggs with milk, honey, and MSG.  Don't knock it 'til you've tried it.

7. My first attempt at creative writing (not for school) may have been a 8 page (or so) children's book I wrote (with crayons and construction paper, of course) when I was about six or seven.  I don't remember what it was about, but I remember my impetus to write it:  In the Sunday funnies, there was a cartoon that had a note suggesting that you could cut it out and use it as a bookmark.  I didn't know what a bookmark was, and when I asked my mom, I misunderstood what she meant, and thought it was something that you glued into the book (for reasons unknown).  Not wanting to ruin any of my books, I decided to just write one myself, just so I could "use my new bookmark."  There's something about this whole story that sums up my creative direction, I think.

1. Open your library (iTunes, Winamp, Media Player, iPod, etc)
2. Put it on shuffle
3. Press play
4. For every question, type the song that's playing
5. When you go to a new question, press the next button
6. Don't lie and try to pretend you're cool..

Okay, has anyone not gotten the first chapter?

At least one person didn't get it, but that may be because of whatever spam filter you're using.  Yahoo's even sent my mail to the spam folder.

Let me know, and we shall fix.

I just sent out a test email (with a jpeg "cover" for "Knock Knock"), so if you've subscribed (we're up to 43 of this writing!), and you didn't get it, or if you want to sign up before everything gets going in two days, email me at mr6@yahoo.com.

Hey, everyone,
 
Sometime last year (okay, the year before), I wrote a 30-chapter mystery novella called "Knock Knock," that I'm just dying to share.
 
The thing is, I feel that when you hand someone a huge stack of paper (and a prose one, at that), it becomes this albatross in their house--that thing that they want to read, but will never get to (I'm sorta guilty of this one myself).
 
My solution?  30 days in April.  30 Chapters.  A chapter a day.  Cliffhanger-style.
 
"Knock Knock," incidentally, is about Anthony Phillip Grover, a.k.a. Tony Bompicelli, a.k.a. "Tony The Bomb," former mobster from Claymore, New Jersey, now living in the Witness Protection Program in the pseudo-liberal town of Iver, Wisconsin. 
 
When a sex offender moves into Tony's neighborhood, Tony does not react well to that.  Not at ALL.   After over a decade of keeping a low profile, Tony's ready to start some major crime again...
 
If you're interested in joining my email subscription list, just send me an email at mr6@yahoo.com and let me know. 
 
Again, this will start April 1st, and you'd receive a chapter a day for the whole month.  Almost every episode ends with a cliffhanger, too, so this'll be a fun read--if you're familiar with my writing, you'll know that I'm kind of a meat-and-potatoes kind of writer--don't expect boring, pretentious, and flowery prose--and DO expect profanity, violence, and all the other stuff your mother warned you about.
 
Feel free, during the process, to send critical or encouraging emails--there may be a good chance that the pages I send out will be revised based on comments and such.
 
And, if all goes well, later this year, you'll see the sequel, tentatively titled "Soccer Moms."
 
Thanks!
 
rob.

No time to talk, but check this out:
 
http://www.nytheatre.com/nytheatre/prnn/369.htm
 
Note to self:  Try not to alienate the NYC critics.

Emily Mills taged me--these are her questions:

1) Can you trace your obsession with dark humor, guns and violence back to any one experience or childhood trauma/joy? I'm curious as to the origins of your thematic bent in writing.

Good question--if there's anything that's affected the overall writing--or at least, the dark, violent stuff, it's that from 5th grade through my sophmore year of high school, I was grossly unpopular and bullied pretty mercilously. Not physically, but the teasing throughout middle school was really viscious and persistant to the extent that (and I've only realized this relatively recently) almost all of my work contains some form of bully somewhere in it.

That said, I also think it may come from the fact that other than that, my childhood was a happy one, and I've always liked my family. I think that sometimes when you haven't been around a lot of trauma, it's easier to view it in a satirical way. As I've gotten older, and experienced more, the work has gotten more and more serious--and that may be because I take pain more seriously now.

2) Who's your favorite historical figure and why?

It seems kind of a cop-out just to say Martin Luther King, like everyone else does, but I guess I'd say him.  

However, if we opened the floor to historical figures that were still alive, I'd go with the little-know performance artist Joey Skaggs. From the late 60's to earlier this decade, Skaggs and his crew have performed hoaxes with one singular purpose:  To prove that the media isn't doing its job.  From setting up phony dog prostitution rings, to diet pills supposedly made from cockroaches, part of the scam was leaving clues in each hoax--ones right out in the front.  Clues that if any reporter did the most basic of fact-checking, they be found out.

He stopped this decade, mainly when the media stopped playing fair.  Part of Skaggs' method is that the reveal of the gag is the most important thing--it's the main message.  Well, when Skaggs released that one of his pranks was a gag, one publication started reporting that they'd "found him out," and that "someone finally outwitted the great Joey Skaggs."  Plus, post 9/11, he said that the government has has less of a sense of humor about the whole thing.  Which is a shame, because now, more than ever, we need a Joey Skaggs.

3) If you ever found yourself in a bar with a lady who had a bomb strapped to her chest, a lady you'd had a less-than secret love for, what would you do? 

Heh.  Whyever do you ask?  ;-)

If I knew how to disarm a bomb, I would--but I think the larger question is would I be willing to die with a woman who I loved--who didn't feel the same way?  

I don't know.  I think I'd stay.  I'd like to think I'd stick it out, even if the love was one-sided. 



4) Name your dream cast for any one of your shows (can be famous people or locals or any mix thereof, doesn't matter). Explain yourself. And don't feel at all bad if it doesn't involve me. :) 

Oh, jeez.  Since it's coming up, I'll dream cast Orange Murder Suit.

As Lynn, the lawyer, I'll say Rachel Griffiths.  Perhaps because people are always bringing up that Molly Vanderlin, who played her originally, kind of resembles her, but also because she can play someone you do not want to fuck with.

As Nina, the mother, I'll say...Mimi Rogers.  My crush on Mimi Rogers is the stuff of legend.

For Joy, the drug addict, I'll say...um...ooh!  Michelle Rodriguez!  She has a toughness you just can't fake.  It's easy to imagine her being brutal.

And for the full version of it, for Julie, the daughter, I'd go with...Kat Dennings.  Granted, I've only seen her in "The 40-year-old Virgin," but she has a quality that might work for the role--Julie is pretty much the only "normal" character in it, and as such, you'd need someone who might not play it too "nice."





5) If you met Christopher Walken and, like the wise man on the mountain, you could only ask him three questions, what would they be?

Oh, jeez...I'd probably ask him one thing:  "How's Lance doing?"

Christopher Walken actually has a brownstone in NYC, right under my dad's friend Lance, and they've been neighbors for years (Lance's wife was housesitting for him the night that he won the Oscar for The Deer Hunter).

In fact, my dad and I went to visit Lance about ten years ago, when I confirmed that, yes, he did really live there (the nameplate said "Walken").  While there, I did my impression--which cracked up Lance--and it suddenly occured to me that there was the tiniest of chances that the real Christopher Walken could have heard it.  

Didn't happen, but it would have been funny.

Okay!

Now: Your mission, should you choose to accept it:

1. Leave me a comment saying, "I too am an egomaniac."
2. I respond by asking you five question. You will answer them, because you like talking about yourself.
3. You will update your LJ with the answers to the questions.
4. You will include this explanation and an offer to interview someone else in the post.
5. When others comment asking to be interviewed, you will ask them five questions. 

[Apparently, it's the LJ tags that are screwing up this entry, so I just removed them.]

So here's the big news:

The Dysfunctional Theatre Company is currently mounting an hour-long version of Orange Murder Suit for the New York Frigid Festival.

It's being directed by my friend and fellow former Broom Streeter Rick Vorndran, who directed me in my first Broom Street play, and it's going to be performed at Under St. Marks. (94 St. Marks Place, between 1st Ave. and Avenue A.)

Here are the dates and times:

Wednesday, March 7th, 6pm Saturday, March 10th, 8:30pm Tuesday, March 13th, 9pm Friday, March 16, 6pm Saturday, March 17th, 4pm

Tickets can be purchased here.

So those of you on the East Coast take note...I will be present for this. Oh, yes.

More news as I get it, but in the meantime, you can learn more about the production here.

Ladies and gentlemen.... My Blitz play. And part two: Let it be said that The Blitz Smackdown was so awesome that I honestly think that every Blitz should be like this. And I know I'm not alone. Thanks to producers Bonnie Balke and Kirk Stantis for putting it together, Rachel Jenkins for doing a great job directing mine, and a wonderful cast for providing some of the best stage combat EVER. (Kelly Lee Kriesel in the doorway is my favorite moment of the night.) More on this later--I'm anxious to get this up.

AUGUSTINA: We can do anything you want, Ben. Okay?

BEN: Good.

AUGUSTINA: Nothing has to happen.

BEN: Excellent.

AUGUSTINA: No pressure.

BEN: No pressure.

AUGUSTINA: We're gonna have fun, Ben.

BEN: I hope so.



900 by Rob Matsushita

At 11:11 pm, the conversation begins. Augustina is a phone sex operator. Ben is a caller.

One game. Two players. They'll either both win...

Or they'll both lose.

900 is a love story in real time--the play ends when the call ends.


-----

AUGUSTINA: When I was a little girl, and I used to go out with my mom shopping, she always used to stop at the used book store and get me one of those digest books, like the Best Of Marvel books. And the first one I got was a Fantastic Four one. She'd shop, and I'd read. I'd just read my Fantastic Four comic book, and I'd feel safe.

BEN: Did you not always feel safe?

AUGUSTINA: Um...we kinda...I hate to do this to you, but...we kinda have to stop talking about me.

BEN: ...I understand.

AUGUSTINA : Is that okay that I said that?

BEN: No, I get it, I, uh, yeah, it's cool. We're cool.

-----

The staged reading of 900 will be at the Mercury Lounge at 117 E Mifflin Street (right next to the Bartell Theater) at 8:00 pm on November 7th (election day!).

Admission is FREE.

900 will be performed by Damon Butler, Kelly Kiorpes, and by director Kathy Lynn Sliter who will be reading stage directions.

Though 900 is just a reading, it contains adult content and is not suitable for younger audiences.


-----

BEN: So the future of the whole human race hinges on girly feelings and unprotected drunk sex?

AUGUSTINA: Oh, like that's a big shocker.

-----

One night only. This performance will be audio recorded.

Oh, and seriously, VOTE. We will ask you if you did.

Hope to see you there.

So last night I had one of those all-at-once ideas for a play about a conversation on a phone sex line, when it occured to me that I honestly don't know the first fracking thing about how Phone Sex Operators work.

This site has been a ton of help--and kind of a fascinating read, too.  My favorite exchange:

Tamer: 

I feel that I failed when they hang up without a goodbye!

Is this normal to just hang up when they are done without a goodbye or anything. I have talked for 25 minutes, can tell by the breathing that they are done and then they are gone. No thanks, see ya, good bye, etc... Should I feel like I failed or is this normal?

angelashingler:

If I tell you that I work in despatch and I've been logged on for the last 3 hours, I've takne 20 calls and I think ONE of the guys said "That was great, Babe. Thanks a lot".

It's understandable - after all, how many of us say 'thanks' to the girl at the supermarket checkout?

jenniferfowler:

Maybe it's just me, but I always preferred that they just hang up

This is a helpful site, but it occurred to me that I might know someone who--or someone who knows someone who has been a PSO at some point so I could ask a few basic questions and bounce the script off them to check it for accuracy.

The big questions:

How does a customer cross the line (regarding asking about the PSO's personal life)?  Is it against policy to discuss any of the realities of the service (how it's run, etc.)?

Does anyone know anyone who can be my expert witness?

MOUSE - Your daemon may be a mouse. You keep your
self hidden away, not because you are ashamed
of it, but because you are afraid the world may
not understand it, and may hurt it. Isn't it
strange how people can be so cruel to such a
small and helpless creature? You want to keep
that very inner part of your psyche private and
close to you, perhaps in your shirt pocket,
next to your heart.

1) Does drink? She can now that she's had the baby!
2) Does have a crush on ? Ummmm...doubtful.
3) What do you disagree with about? Which Cheap Trick song is the COOLEST. EEEEE!
4) If was a superhero, who would be his/her archnemesis? Jerky McManface. That guy's a jerk.
5) What rank would have in a giant robot army? Lt. But we'd pronounce it "Leftentant," because that sounds cooler.
6) If took over the world, who would suffer? Calista Flockhart.
7) What flavor of jello would be? My instinct says lime. Definitely not grape. Possibly cherry.
8) If had a superpower, what would it be? Bashing people with his mighty mighty fists.
9) Would you make out with ? Y'know, I would. That's just the sort of thing I'd do. I mean, if she wasn't married, since her husband just a real nice fella.
10) Is related to you? Not by blood. Only by our commitment to low, low prices.
11) Does travel a lot? She may now, given the way I've answered question 9.
12) Does smoke? Only when she's in one of my shows, and even then, only fictionally.
13) What is 's shoe size? I'm gonna guess 12.
14) Does know ? All too well.
15) What is 's biggest flaw? The need to fit the words "Emmanuel Lewis" and "handjob" in the same song title.
16) What is 's favorite band/artist? She's been keen on the Peter Gabriel lately.
17) What would you do if died? What an awful question! (Especially given my answers to the last questions with her I answered) I'd probably feel really bad about killing her in Irish Lesbian Vampire 2, that's for damn sure.
18) What would do differently in your shoes? He has a better sense of when to keep his opinions to himself than I do, that's for sure.
19) One quality you find attractive in ? Her sparkling eyes. And the fact that she'll TOTALLY do anything on a dare. (Okay, not really)
20) What word best describes ? FAAAAAABULOUS!
21) How long have you known ? Long enough to have shared a hotel room at least once.
22) Do you think is hot? I refuse to answer on the grounds that then she'd know I think she's hot.
23) What would give for his/her birthday? A stunning combination of shoes and chotchke. Shoetchke, if you will.
24) How many monkeys could fight at once and win against? One, if it was long enough. No, wait.
25) What comic book character would be? DUFFMAN. Oh, yeah!
26) Which president would be likely to idolize? William Henry Harrison. She would have been able to talk him into wearing a fucking JACKET, that's for sure.
27) Have you flirted with ? Oh, I must have, at some point. I must've.
28) Is 1337? He is teh roxxors.
29) 's hair color? Trick question.
30) Are and going out? No, but I almost wish they would, just to be a fly on the wall for THAT first date.

Easy
Your life has been 28% difficult.
Based on your family, money, political context, and personal situation -- during the important years of your development -- it appears your life was EASY. What does this mean?

Well, the "difficulty" of your life is a measure of how rough you had it. Relative to the world, you had a pretty good childhood. I'm not saying it was really easy, just that you weren't gnawing on a belt for calories. Still though, it wasn't perfect.

I'm not sure what "success" means to you, but whatever it is, you can achieve it. When you do, it'll be that much more impressive.
My test tracked 1 variable How you compared to other people your age and gender:
You scored higher than 47% on difficult

I'll screen the comments for now so that everyone can guess without seeing each other's guesses.

1.  "Well, some white ASSHOLE took the last piece-of-shit sky-blue Cadillac on the lot."

2.  "See that?  Boom. Still alive.  Now we question him.  Y'know why?  'Cause I got him in the leg.  I didn't pump him full of bullets and jump off a building with him."  "Hey, that's no fair, the building guy lived."

But, if you do decide to have the baby, then, at that very moment, when you're absolutely sure, tell David.  Tell him at that exact second, and then you spoil that kid every chance you get."

8.  "He gave me a picture of you once.  I never knew why.  It was very old. Torn. Faded.  You were young, like you are now.  You weren't smiling...just a little sad...  I always wondered what you were thinking at that second."

10.  " I stopped by here to tell you two things. Number one is that you're going to die tonight. Number two, I'm going to go home, have a nice hot meal, then I'm gonna find your wife and I'm going to kill her too."

A letter to the Rob of 1986:

Hey, it's me again.

First things first, Bridget is a dead-end.  You'll think you're going to get there, but--and this important--no matter what happens, it will never happen between you two.  The good news is that this does not impact your life in any real way.  The better news is that the cooler girls are waiting just in the wings.  There's one who's going to pop up in just four years, who--well, I won't spoil it for you.

Right about now, you may be wondering what to do once you graduate high school.  Well, the bad news is that your grades just plain suck, so Montclair State isn't happpening.

The good news is, this also does not affect your life in any real way.

When you do go to a college, and you pick your major--right now, you're thinking of film--make sure you're lining up your career before you gradute--and while we're on the subject, no matter how tempting it is, don't take too light a class load.  It seems like you've got a lot of free time, but you'll just be spinning your wheels.

By the way, do NOT count on your advisor to help you figure out your class schedule.  You need to do this on your own, or it won't happen.

Learn to drive.  Seriously.  It's not that hard, and once you start, you'll love it.

Okay, here's where things get scary.

You have to leave the nest.  Study abroad.  Leave Jersey.  You can always come back.  There is no reason to be afraid of travel.  (Consider L.A.  SERIOUSLY CONSIDER L.A.)

I debated telling you all sorts of other things to avoid, personal situations, professional situations...well, I hate to say this, but I'm not going to.

It sucks, I know, but if you don't fuck up here and there, you might never take any chances and you might not learn.

(Although I will say that if you attempt standup comedy, it WILL GO BADLY.)

Here's one big piece of personal advice:  You first girlfriend is coming up soon.  Two years from now.  Don't get too excited, you haven't met her yet.  Obviously, since I used the word "first," that means that it won't last forever between you too.

My big piece of advice is that that is okay.  Don't sweat it. 

And for Christ's sake, don't get obessive and weird about it...when it's over...really, just let her go.  I only tell you this because there's a chance you could miss out on a few other opportunities.  Girls will stay away if you're still focused on Girl #1.

LET.  IT.  GO.

The friends you are making now, amazingly, will be some of your best friends.  Amazingly, you will still have several of them when you're my age.  Friendship is the most important thing you've got in this world.  Treasure them.  (Just don't get creepy about it.)

Keep writing.  And don't be afraid to get into trouble from time to time.  Just make sure you don't get caught.

Also, you're only going to be able to drink alcohol for another ten years.  Allergies.  Ask Dad.

And, well, I guess that's it. 

Oh, and there's a film director you should look up:  John Woo.  Trust me, you'll love him.

Love,

Your Pal,  Rob Of The Future.

p.s.  Don't bother seeing any live-action Batman movie until the year 2005. You're just going to get angry.

The schedule includes: "Oklahomo: A Gay Comedy About Curley, a Resident Drag Queen, a Transexual Cow and Homophobia," by Ron Collins, June 10-July 17; "Sledgehammer Party: An Amusing Drama About Murder, Sex, Death and Partying," by Rob Matsushita, July 29-Sept. 4; "Tales for Another Millennium: A Comedy in Which Jesus and His Parents Mary and God Screw Up the Universe One More Time," by Brian Wild, Sept. 16- Oct. 23; and "The Most Beautiful Jew in the World: A Comedy About Clothing Designer Ralph Lauren," by Joel Gersmann, Nov. 11-Dec. 18.

AAAAAAGH!!!   Why does Joel have to MAKE UP STUFF when he's doing publicity!

THAT'S NOT THE TITLE.  THAT IS NOT THE TITLE.

AAAAAGH!!!!
